Revised by Sarah Quick, Reference Archivist.Brooklyn CollectionBrooklyn Collection128 Pierrepont StBrooklyn, NY 11201bcref@bklynlibrary.orgThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2021-01-12T18:32:46eng
Brooklyn Collection
Rainone-Morra Family Papers
Morra Family
Rainone Family
BCMS.0022
0.5 Cubic feet in 1 document box
1921-1950 Letters to and from various members of the Rainone and Morra Families.
Biographical Note
Carlo and Elisa Rainone immigrated from Italy in 1890 and 1888 respectively. In 1910 they were settled at 100 Ralph Avenue in Brooklyn, with a large family, supported by Carlo's work as a barber. Their daughter Mary, born around 1898, would later marry pharmacist Ernest Morra, some of whose papers are included in this collection. Other family members were Lucy Beatrice (b. September 29, 1898,), Michael C. (b. 1900), Carmela (b. 7 Jan 1901), Adelina (born Feb 2 or 7, 1902), and Julia A. (b. 1903).
Michael C. went to Bushwick High School and studied medicine at the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital, graduating in 1928, and obtaining his New York State license to practice medicine in 1930. He enjoyed bowling and was President of the Silver Dollar Club of Kings County in 1942.
Julia, born 23 Feb 1903, worked in the New York City School system, whether as a teacher or a clerical assistant is not clear. Lucy was a stenographer who aspired to be a published author, with little or no success. She seems to have enjoyed reading horoscopes, belonged to a Republican Club, was a practicing Catholic and gave money to at least one Catholic charity.
By 1930 Mary was married and the rest of the family had moved to 844 Putnam Avenue. She and her husband Ernest Morra (born 24 Feb 1894), a pharmacist sometimes referred to as "Dr. Morra," lived at 259 Stuyvesant Avenue. Ernest Morra managed a branch of Liggett's Drug Store located at 954 Madison Avenue in Manhattan. Evidently a successful businessman, he received numerous letters from the management of Liggett's congratulating him on increased revenues, and by the late 1920s was buying shares in pharmaceutical companies.
Carlo Rainone died on February 23, 1945 at the family home on Putnam Avenue and was interred at St. John's Cemetery. At some point thereafter, Julia, Lucy, Carmela (sometimes called Camilla) and Adelina moved to 11201 84th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, where Lucy died in June of 1973. Camilla followed in March 1976. Adelina passed away in February 1980 and Julia in October 1981. Ernest Morra also died in Queens in March 1984.
Arrangement
This collection is arranged in five folders. The materials belonging to Lucy B. Rainone, Julia A. Rainone, Michael C. Rainone and Ernest Morra are foldered by individual. Materials from other Rainone family members are gathered in one folder.
Scope and Contents
This is a small collection of papers belonging to several members of one Italian-American family living in Brooklyn in the early to mid-twentieth century. Each family member kept papers that were important to him or her: for Ernest Morra, documentation of his business successes; for Michael Rainone, his certification as a doctor; for Lucy, her writing; for Julia, a few personal letters; and for Adelina, invitations to events.
The collection also includes several photographs sent by Louis Rainone (whose relationship to the rest of the family is not clear) to various family members from his postings abroad during World War II.
Access
Collection is located in the Brooklyn Collection at the Central Branch at Grand Army Plaza. The collection may only be used in the library and is not available through interlibrary loan. Requests to view the collection must be made at least 48 hours in advance of visit.
Use
While many items in the Brooklyn Collection are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
Provenance
This collection was donated by the Queens Library in 2009.
Related Archival Materials note
Brooklyn Clipping Files- Italian Americans
Casalena, Josephine. A portrait of the Italian-American community in New York City. Congress of Italian-American Organization. 1975.
Hutchens, Nancy Cheryl. Recent Italian immigrants in Brooklyn : their social worlds. University Microfilms International. 1986, c1977.
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as the Rainone-Morra Family Papers, Brooklyn Public Library – Brooklyn Collection.
Correspondence Drugstores Italian Americans Italians—United States
Letters to and from Lucy B. Rainone11
General
Lucy B. Rainone was the author of several unpublished short stories. Some of her correspondence documents repeated attempts to find a publisher for her work. It also includes letters relating to a tax audit in 1922 and miscellaneous other items.Letters to and from Julia A. Rainone12
General
Julia's materials inlcude three letters in Italian from Dr. Bruno Branchini, an acquaintance of her friend Frances Bernstein, in which Dr Branchini hopes for continuing friendship. Other letters concern her employment, including a "Teacher Clerk license" allowing her to work at Brooklyn Boys' Continuation School.Letters to and from Michael C. Rainone13
General
Medical examination results, certifications and a recommendation.Miscellaneous Rainone family papers14
General
Several invitations, with ribbons, to Miss Adelina V. Rainone to attend Annual Dinners of the City Bank Quarter Century Club. Adelina was presumably employed at the bank. There are also a few clippings from the Brooklyn Daily Eagle and other sources, some of them noting the sisters' travels.Letters to and from Ernest Morra15
General
Principally relating to his pharmacy on Madison Avenue, these papers also include a tax return for 1920 and notices of stock purchases.
